title: High-dose Insulin Euglycemia Therapy (HIET)
description: Calculates insulin dosing for calcium channel blocker or beta blocker overdose. Provides both initial bolus and continuous infusion doses, along with dextrose requirements to maintain euglycemia.

ranges.interpretation: Follow the calculated protocol with close monitoring. Check glucose every 30 minutes for 1-2 hours until stable. Monitor potassium hourly. Continue until hemodynamic improvement achieved.

references: Holger JS, Stellpflug SJ, Cole JB, Harris CR, Engebretsen KM. High-dose insulin: a consecutive case series in toxin-induced cardiogenic shock. Clin Toxicol (Phila). 2011 Aug;49(7):653-8.

Greene SL, Gawarammana I, Wood DM, Jones AL, Dargan PI. Relative safety of hyperinsulinaemia/euglycaemia therapy in the management of calcium channel blocker overdose: a prospective observational study. Intensive Care Med. 2007 Nov;33(11):2019-24.
Engebretsen KM, Kaczmarek KM, Morgan J, Holger JS. High-dose insulin therapy in beta-blocker and calcium channel-blocker poisoning. Clin Toxicol (Phila). 2011 Apr;49(4):277-83.
formula: Insulin Bolus = 1 unit/kg IV; Initial Infusion = 0.5-1 unit/kg/hr; Dextrose = 0.5 g/kg/hr
notes: For calcium channel blocker or beta blocker-induced myocardial depression
Monitor for hypoglycemia and hypokalemia closely
Hypoglycemia can occur hours after insulin infusion stops
Concentrate insulin solutions to prevent fluid overload
May require up to 10 units/kg/hr in severe cases
Typical duration is 1-2 days, but may extend to 4 days
Give dextrose 25-50g bolus if glucose <250 mg/dL
